title: Why should we worry about sustainability?
displayTitle: Why should we worry about sustainability?
body:
Open data needs to remain relevant, up to date and accessible to be useful. Together, these three qualities make up the sustainability of a dataset

A sustainable programme is one that continues to regularly release data with maintained or improving quality and quantity

For something to be sustainable it is ‘able to be maintained at a certain rate or level’

For an open data release to be sustainable, it must maintain regular updates with at least the same level of quality and quantity.

In this module we'll look at:
  • How to make sense of sustainability
  • Why sustainability matters to you
  • What tell-tale signs to look for in open datasets

title: All about open data sustainability – in two minutes
displayTitle: All about open data sustainability – in two minutes
body: The ODI’s Ulrich Atz explains the importance of sustainability in open data, why the concept matters to users and talks through some of the key indicators that an open data release is built to last

title: What makes open data sustainable?
body:
A sustainable open dataset always has three things behind it:
  • Secure funding to cover the cost of updates
  • Active supportof publishers to prioritise updates
  • Wide reuse by other people to demonstrate the value

title: Making sense of sustainability in open data
displayTitle: Making sense of sustainability in open data
body: What factors contribute to making an open dataset sustainable?

_items.title: Secure funding?
_items.body:
Just because a dataset can be freely used does not mean it does not have a cost to collect and release. Funding can be secured through many means:
  • Charging for access or enhanced services
  • Making open data core to the organisation practice
  • Owned by the taxpayer or funder

_items.title: Active support
_items.body:
Sustainable data requires both the backing of an organisation’s management and the support of staff responsible for maintaining the quality

Active support is most commonly achieved by a company committing to maintain open data as part of their daily operations.

_items.title: Wide reuse
_items.body: Sustainable reuse is achieved when the services created with that data become critical to the success of the publisher’s business. For example, Transport for London data feeds are used by millions when they access transport apps like citymapper. These apps drive usage of TfL services and as such TfL have a commitment in their digital strategy to regularly update the data.

title: Why does sustainability matter?
body: Why should I care about whether the open data I work with is sustainable?

_items.title: Solid foundations
_items.body:
Sustainability is not just good for the users. The publisher also benefits from a sustainable open data programme by:
  • Enhancing the trust of the community in the publisher’s organization
  • Supporting the creation of new products and services
  • Simplifying the publishers reuse of their own data

_items.title: Enhances trust
_items.body: In a world of constant scrutiny, sustainable open data allows a large community to build and analyse data in order to draw their own conclusions, often in support of a publishers view

_items.title: Builds business connections
_items.body: Sustained open data has the power to unlock new customer channels, enabling other business to build on a publisher's data. In many cases these businesses provide direct benefits back to the publisher

_items.title: Improves data usability
_items.body: One of the biggest reusers of a publisher's data may well be the publisher. Why separate the public release of data from the internal data usage?

title: Looking for clues
body: A sustainable release combines secure funding, active support and  wide reuse. These traits are not always obvious when you first find a dataset. Ask yourself the following to help spot good sources:

_items.title: What is the source?
_items.body:
Ask yourself who has released the data and how much confidence do you have in their commitment to continue updating it?

One of the most important indicators of sustainability is how confident you feel in the organisation who collects it.

If the data is from government, might an election or a change in priority affect the release?

_items.title: Who is funding the release?
_items.body:
Data available at no cost appears ideal, however ask yourself how a publisher is funding the sustained release?

As yourself if the data is being released because of transparency pressures, or if there is a wider beneficial use driving demand

Try and find out if there is a specific short term programme funding the data availability or is the release part of the core strategy of the organisation?

_items.title: What does the license say?
_items.body:
Licenses can also offer clues about sustainability

When looking at a license, ask yourself what does the text hint about the future of the dataset and confidence of the publisher? Does it contain a commitment to update regularly?

Remember that without a license, data is not truly open. The licence gives you certainty that data can be freely used and shared.

_items.alt: Who is already using the data?
_items.title: Who is already using the data?
_items.body:
The more widely a dataset is used, the more pressure there is for it to be sustained

Ask yourself who else is using this dataset and for what purposes?

Try and find if the dataset is used internally by the publisher themselves?

Both aspects are important in order to discover if the publisher cares about the dataset themselves (through their own use) and has external pressure to not remove access or change it only for their purposes.

_items.title: What is the publishing history?
_items.body:
Sustainability is ultimately about how much trust you place in the publisher

One of the best ways to make up your mind about how someone will behave in the future is to look at how they have behaved in the past

Ask yourself how long the dataset has been published for? A long history of updates is a good sign, but beware external factors such as project lengths or terms in office. A key indicator of a sustained initiative is one that outlives these external factors.

_items.title: How can I contribute?
_items.body:
Using the dataset yourself will help drive the demand and thus influence the sustainability

Think about joining any communities of practice that exist around the dataset

Try and find out if the publisher plays an active role in this community and do they act upon feedback to improve their services?

sk yourself what value you can demonstrate that will enhance the sustainability provided by the publisher?

title: Are you sure?
body: Which of these does not influence the sustainability of an open dataset

title: What should I look for when assessing sustainability?
displayTitle: What should I look for when assessing sustainability?
body: What tell-tale signs should you look for when assessing the sustainability of an open dataset?

_items.text: Who is already using the data?
What format is the data in?

_feedback.correct: Looking for the publishing history, who is using the data and how it is paid for are all key questions to ask when determining the sustainability of the dataset.

_incorrect.notFinal: Looking for the publishing history, who is using the data and how it is paid for are all key questions to ask when determining the sustainability of the dataset.
_incorrect.final: Looking for the publishing history, who is using the data and how it is paid for are all key questions to ask when determining the sustainability of the dataset.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Looking for the publishing history, who is using the data and how it is paid for are all key questions to ask when determining the sustainability of the dataset.
_partlyCorrect.final: Looking for the publishing history, who is using the data and how it is paid for are all key questions to ask when determining the sustainability of the dataset.

title: Summary
body:
In this module, we have learned how you can evaluate the sustainability of an open data release. You can use these techniques to identify sustainable sources of data and give you the confidence to work with them long-term.

What you have learned
  • What influences the sustainability of a dataset
  • Why sustainability matters to you
  • How to spot tell-tale signs of sustainability
This project is funded by the European Commision's Connecting Europe Facility
